description: India-specific baby milestone quiz. Age-banded questions written for Indian parents. Weights reflect clinical significance at each age.

questions.question: During tummy time on a soft mat, does your baby try to lift their head?
questions.hint: Even lifting the chin briefly off the surface counts. Start with 1–2 minutes of tummy time after a feed.

questions.question: Do both your baby's arms and legs move equally on both sides?
questions.hint: Both sides should move symmetrically. Consistently favouring one side may need a paediatrician's review.

questions.question: Does your baby turn their head or look towards your voice when you call them?
questions.hint: They do not need to understand words yet — just reacting to sound and your familiar voice counts.

options.label: No reaction to voices or sounds

questions.question: Does your baby follow your face or a colourful toy with their eyes when you move it slowly?
questions.hint: Hold a bright dupatta or toy about 20–30 cm from their face and move it slowly side to side.

questions.question: Has your baby given you a real social smile (not just wind) when you smile at them?
questions.hint: A social smile appears around 6 weeks. It comes when they see your face — not just randomly.

options.label: Yes, smiles back when I smile
I have seen it once or twice

questions.question: When you hold your baby upright, does their head stay steady without wobbling?
questions.hint: By 4 months most babies have good head control. Support their head only if needed.

questions.question: Has your baby rolled from their tummy to their back?
questions.hint: Rolling from tummy to back usually comes before rolling from back to tummy. Place them on a firm surface and watch.

options.label: Has done it once or twice

questions.question: Does your baby reach out and grab a rattle or toy when it is held in front of them?
questions.hint: By 4 months babies start intentionally reaching. Hold the toy just within their arm reach.

options.label: Notices it but does not grab yet

questions.question: Does your baby bring their hands to their mouth and explore their fingers?
questions.hint: Hand-to-mouth play is a normal part of this age. It helps babies learn about their body.

questions.question: Does your baby make cooing or vowel sounds ('aaa', 'ooo', 'eee') when you talk to them?
questions.hint: This is your baby's first 'conversation'. Pause after you speak — they may coo back.

options.label: Yes, coos and makes sounds often

questions.question: Does your baby laugh or giggle — not just smile, but make a sound of joy?
questions.hint: First laughs usually appear around 3–4 months. Try funny faces or gentle tickles.

questions.question: Does your baby turn their head to look for the source of a sound (a rattle, a voice from across the room)?
questions.hint: Shake a rattle out of sight and watch if they search for it.

questions.question: Does your baby get excited — kicking legs or waving arms — when they see you or another familiar family member approach?
questions.hint: Look for anticipatory excitement before you even pick them up.

questions.question: Can your baby sit on the floor without support for at least a few seconds?
questions.hint: By 6 months most babies sit with hands on the floor for balance; full independent sitting usually comes by 9 months.

questions.question: When you hold your baby upright with feet touching the floor, do they bear some weight on their legs?
questions.hint: They do not need to stand alone — just pushing down on their legs when held counts.

questions.question: Does your baby transfer an object (such as a small toy or spoon) from one hand to the other?
questions.hint: Give them a light rattle and watch if they pass it hand to hand.

options.label: Has done it a few times

questions.question: Does your baby use a raking motion with their fingers to pull a small puffed snack towards themselves?
questions.hint: Place a small, safe puffed piece (like a baby puff or soft cereal) on a flat surface and watch how they try to pick it up.

options.label: No interest or cannot pick up

questions.question: Does your baby babble with consonant sounds — strings like 'babababa', 'mamama', 'dadada'?
questions.hint: This is different from random cooing. Listen for repeated syllables.

questions.question: Does your baby respond to their own name by looking up or turning towards you?
questions.hint: Say their name from across the room without using gestures and see if they look.

options.label: Rarely, only if you are close

questions.question: If you drop a toy in front of your baby, do they look down to find where it went?
questions.hint: This shows the beginning of object permanence — understanding that things still exist when out of sight.

options.label: Just stares at where it was

questions.question: Does your baby enjoy peek-a-boo? Do they laugh or look for your face when you reappear?
questions.hint: Cover your face with your hands or a cloth and reappear. Watch for anticipation and laughter.

questions.question: Does your baby crawl on hands and knees, commando-crawl on their tummy, or move around the floor in their own way?
questions.hint: Any method of floor mobility counts — bottom shuffling, rolling, or commando crawl. Some babies skip crawling and go straight to standing.

options.label: Rolls to move but no crawl
Not moving around the floor yet

questions.question: Does your baby pull themselves to standing using the cot, sofa, or low table for support?
questions.hint: This is a key milestone that usually comes between 9–12 months.

options.label: Has done it once or twice

questions.question: Does your baby pick up a small soft piece of food using just their thumb and first finger (pincer grasp)?
questions.hint: The pincer grasp develops around 9–10 months. Place a small, soft piece of food in front of them and watch how they pick it up.

questions.question: Does your baby put small objects into a container and then take them back out?
questions.hint: Use a bowl and safe objects like soft blocks. In-and-out play develops understanding of containers.

options.label: Yes, puts in and takes out
Takes things out but not in

questions.question: Does your baby say 'mama', 'dada', or an equivalent first parent word and clearly mean you when they say it?
questions.hint: Babbling 'mamama' does not count — they should be saying it to get your attention or call you specifically.

questions.question: Does your baby understand simple familiar words like 'water', 'no', or 'bye' even if they cannot say them yet?
questions.hint: Say 'no' and see if they pause. Ask for water and see if they look at the glass or cup.

questions.question: Does your baby clap hands or wave goodbye when you model it?
questions.hint: Imitation is a key cognitive milestone. Clap your hands or wave and see if they copy you.

options.label: Watches but does not copy yet

questions.question: Does your baby show stranger anxiety — becoming clingy or upset when an unfamiliar person holds them?
questions.hint: Stranger anxiety is a healthy developmental sign showing your baby knows who is safe.

questions.question: Does your baby walk independently without holding any support?
questions.hint: First independent steps usually come between 10–15 months. Walking with support (cruising) does not count here.

questions.question: Does your baby climb onto low furniture like the diwan or sofa on their own?
questions.hint: Climbing is an important gross motor milestone at this age. Ensure safe spaces to explore.

options.label: Gets on bum but not knees

questions.question: Can your baby stack 2–3 blocks or cups on top of each other?
questions.hint: Block stacking requires good hand-eye coordination and develops around 12–15 months.

questions.question: Does your baby scribble with a crayon or pencil when you give them one?
questions.hint: Any mark on paper counts — they do not need to draw a shape. Show them first.

options.label: Has made marks a few times
Holds it but does not mark

questions.question: How many meaningful words does your baby use — in any language (Hindi, Tamil, Bengali, or any other)?
questions.hint: Count all consistent words in all languages spoken at home — any word used with clear meaning counts.

questions.question: Can your baby point to at least 2 body parts (nose, eyes, feet, etc.) when you name them?
questions.hint: Ask 'Where is your nose?' or 'Show me your eyes' without pointing yourself. Use your home language.

questions.question: Does your baby follow simple 2-word instructions without gestures, like 'get the ball' or 'give me' + an object?
questions.hint: Keep your hands still when you ask — do not point. Use your home language; the language does not matter, only whether they understand.

questions.question: Does your baby show affection — giving hugs, kisses (pyaar), or snuggling into you voluntarily?
questions.hint: Affection should feel spontaneous, not just in response to prompting.

options.label: Only when I ask for a hug

questions.question: Does your baby run — not just walk fast, but actually run with both feet briefly off the ground?
questions.hint: Running usually develops a few months after walking begins. Watch them on open ground.

options.label: Walks very fast but does not run

questions.question: Can your baby kick a ball that is placed in front of them?
questions.hint: Place a soft ball on the floor and ask them to kick it. Walking up and stopping in front of it counts as progress.

options.label: Walks to it but loses balance

questions.question: Can your baby turn the pages of a board book — one page at a time?
questions.hint: Board books are best at this age. Turning thick pages develops pincer strength.

options.label: Yes, turns pages one at a time

questions.question: Does your baby try to feed themselves with a spoon — scooping food from a bowl and bringing it to their mouth?
questions.hint: Spilling is completely fine at this age. The attempt to use a spoon independently is what matters.

options.label: Holds spoon but uses hands to eat

questions.question: Does your baby combine two words to make short phrases — like 'more water', 'daddy come', or 'car gone'?
questions.hint: Any language or mix of languages is fine. What matters is that they are combining two meaningful words together.

options.label: Has done it a few times

questions.question: Roughly how many different words does your baby use — counting all languages spoken at home?
questions.hint: By 18 months most babies have around 20 words; by 24 months around 50+. Count words across all languages spoken at home.

questions.question: Can your baby sort objects by shape or colour — for example, putting all round pieces in one pile and square in another?
questions.hint: Use a simple shape-sorter toy or two bowls. Basic sorting is expected by around 18–24 months.

options.label: Can do it with a little guidance

questions.question: Does your baby pretend to do everyday things — like feeding their toy doll or teddy from a pretend bowl, or pretend-talking on a toy phone?
questions.hint: Pretend play shows symbolic thinking. Look for them imitating household activities they have seen.

questions.question: When playing near another child (cousin, neighbour's child), does your baby play alongside them — even if not together?
questions.hint: Parallel play (playing side by side without direct interaction) is normal and healthy at this age.

options.label: Stays close to me, avoids others
